message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT angiography and diffusion-weighted MRI show a large occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery. IV tPA should be administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset, but since the patient had a similar episode 2 months ago, the time period for administering IV tPA has already passed. Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent used for secondary stroke prevention, but it is not effective for treatment of acute ischemic stroke. Mannitol is used to decrease intracranial pressure in cases of cerebral edema, but it is not indicated for treatment of acute ischemic stroke. Mechanical thrombectomy is the best course of treatment in this patient, as it is effective up to 24 hours after symptom onset and has been shown to improve outcomes in large vessel occlusions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibit shows a large left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarct, which suggests an occlusion of the M1 branch of the MCA. The best course of treatment in this patient is mechanical thrombectomy, which can remove the clot and restore blood flow to the affected area, reducing the risk of further brain damage. IV tPA can also be used in eligible patients but is less effective in large vessel occlusions like this one. Aspirin is useful for the prevention of stroke but is not effective in treating acute stroke. Mannitol is a diuretic that can reduce brain swelling but is not indicated in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibit shows a large occlusion in the left middle cerebral artery, which is a severe ischemic stroke. Therefore, the best course of treatment would be mechanical thrombectomy to remove the clot and restore blood flow to the affected area of the brain. IV tPA and aspirin are also used to treat ischemic strokes, but mechanical thrombectomy is recommended for large-vessel occlusions like in this case. Mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure in cases of cerebral edema, which is not indicated in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibited MRI shows an acute cerebral infarction, and the patient’s symptoms suggest a left middle cerebral artery territory stroke. IV tPA can be used in eligible patients within 3 to 4.5 hours of symptom onset but a history of recent MI within the past 3 months is a contraindication. Aspirin can be given for secondary prevention after 24 hours of symptom onset but not for acute treatment. Mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, which is not indicated in this case. Mechanical thrombectomy can be performed in patients with acute ischemic stroke due to a large artery occlusion in specific circumstances, such as in this patient with a large vessel occlusion in the middle cerebral artery territory.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibit shows a clot in the left M1 segment of the middle cerebral artery, indicating a large vessel occlusion. IV tPA is recommended within 4.5 hours of onset of symptoms but is contraindicated in patients with a large vessel occlusion. Mechanical thrombectomy is the best course of treatment in this patient. Aspirin is used for secondary prevention in patients with ischemic stroke and Mannitol is used to decrease intracranial pressure in patients with cerebral edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image exhibits a clot in the M1 segment of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA), causing an ischemic stroke. As the patient arrived within the therapeutic window of 24 hours, and there is a large-vessel occlusion, mechanical thrombectomy is the best course of treatment. IV tPA is not recommended as the patient had a recent MI and there is a risk of bleeding. Aspirin is not sufficient for a large-vessel occlusion. Mannitol is used for reducing intracranial pressure in certain situations, but not for treating an ischemic stroke.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of a stroke, and the MRI shows an acute ischemic infarct in the left MCA territory. The best course of treatment for an acute ischemic stroke with large vessel occlusion is mechanical thrombectomy. IV tPA is only effective within 4.5 hours of symptom onset, and in this case, the patient’s symptoms started 5 hours ago. Aspirin is not effective for an acute ischemic stroke with large vessel occlusion. Mannitol is used for intracranial pressure management in specific cases and is not effective for acute ischemic stroke.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibit shows a large clot in the left middle cerebral artery, leading to the patient’s neurological symptoms. tPA is contraindicated as the patient had a recent MI and his symptoms started more than 4.5 hours ago. Aspirin is not enough to dissolve the clot. Mannitol is used for brain swelling, which is not present in this case. Therefore, the best course of treatment is mechanical thrombectomy to remove the clot and restore blood flow to the affected area of the brain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibit shows a large left middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarct with a clot in the M1 segment of the left MCA. IV tPA is not recommended in patients with large MCA infarcts, as the risk of hemorrhage outweighs the benefit. Aspirin alone is not sufficient for treatment of an MCA infarct. Mannitol is not indicated in ischemic stroke. Mechanical thrombectomy is the most appropriate treatment for large MCA infarcts, especially if performed within 6-24 hours of symptom onset, as in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an acute ischemic stroke, and the images support this diagnosis. IV tPA can be considered if given within 4.5 hours of symptom onset, but this patient’s symptoms have been present for more than 5 hours. Aspirin should be given within 48 hours of symptom onset but is not the best immediate treatment option. Mannitol is used for cerebral edema, which is not present in this case. Mechanical thrombectomy is the best course of treatment for this patient, as it can be effective for removing the clot causing the stroke.
